ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about how to take an economic approach to education, applying models to examples such as charter schools. I also learned about specific court cases, such as Serrano v. Priest and Brown v. Board of Education, and how to generate an effective regression model.
I learned a lot about the inequality of education in the past and present day. Other than that I did not learn much and found this class to be very tedious and unenjoyable.
I learned some judicial concepts and history of urban inequalities in the US
How to apply economics to bigger issues like inequalities in school districts
I learned things about american education history through court cases, laws, and viewpoints on how education systems could be statistically studied.
I gained a deeper understanding of how to look at economic studies through a more skeptical lens.
None
A better understanding of educational inequality
Team work skills
Learned about the history of educational inequality in the US with some emphasis on constitutional law and statistical processes
Good
Educational systems
Econ
Literally nothing. I learned more about the topics we were supposed to be learning about in this course in a different course that I was taking in the same semester.
interpreting law
I learned a lot about the basis that makes up the current public education system financially.
Honestly not much
I learned about the beginnings of inequality in urban societies.
Basic urban and educational inequalities knowledge
Learned a lot about inequality in school throughout history.
I learned a lot more about the history of educational inequality in America and how deeply influenced it is by race.
Inequalities in education
critical reading

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought that this course was good theoretically, but the lectures were a bit dense and not particularly engaging. I enjoyed when the professor told stories about himself or provided specific examples, but the class felt a bit redundant and more historical than topical, which I would have preferred. I also enjoyed the idea of group work, but in practice, found it difficult to coordinate and ultimately stressful. The Canvas page also often had conflicting deadlines for assignments, which was confusing.

Group projects were very disorganized and frankly unfair. Many students were left to pick up the pieces of other students because their grades depened on it. Grading system was also very random and unstructured.
It wasn't hard, but didn't learned much.
Strengths: Interesting topics and good historical background of the topics covered.
Better lecture notes on power point slides during class

Strengths: interesting content, the professor has a lot of lived experiences that lend well to the course, light workload.
Weaknesses: there are 3 group projects for this course, one of them being a 15-20 page final paper, and I had a terrible experience with my group.
Lectures were very disorganized and lecture slides were not posted to gain a better understanding of the class. I often left lectures realising that I had not really learned anything.
Strength--Professor Jaynes is an awesome professor who is very knowledgable on the topic.
Terrible class.
The course is somewhat disorganized and unstructured
Weaknesses: Assignments are often incredibly vague and open ended. Group projects not always conducive to best engagement with the material.
Choose own group for assignments

Strength: the material is really interesting, definitely different than other economics classes I've taken
Weakness: there's an emphasis on forced collaboration that is very dependent on your team arrangement
Not get to choose your own groups for the papers was horrible
Good
Lectures were dry. I wish there was more guidance on assignments
Good lectures

Pros
- Gut!!! 
- There are no exams.
- Class is only 50 minutes
- Readings are short (6-10 pages), but kinda optional as Prof. will go over the important bits from the readings in lecture anyway.
- Workload is light. There are 3 one-page homework assignments to be done individually and two group papers (5 and 15 pages).
- Virtually no math. If you can add and subtract, youre good.

Cons
- There are surprise quizzes during class. These are easy and usually last a minute (their true goal is to foster attendance), but they can still be a source of unneeded anxiety.
- The final paper is a group project and counts for 40% of the grade. You will either be in a good group or a bad group.
- The readings are really old. Some were published in the 1960s.

This class is the actual worst, ignore people telling you to take it b/c it is easy. It is easy - there are just four total assignments, all of which are super short and not that hard + one group paper at the end. But, grading makes no sense and feels totally random/arbitrary, plus working in a group is so unnecessarily challenging. You will learn NOTHING in lecture, even when they're about topics that should be cool. Basically, this class is NOT AT ALL worth it, you will learn nothing and there are many other guts (including within the econ department) that are at least kinda interesting. Seriously, no one should take this course, it is by far the worst class I have ever taken at Yale.
a bit banal, but very nice professor
I believe the material for this class is very intriguing in the issues they raise, but at times, there seemed to be too much of it.
The class was very disengaging. Everyone mostly just did their own thing in class and the only effort people put in was during their papers.
I do not think that the course was taught very well. I feel that the professor often was hard to follow in lecture and sometimes homework instructions were unclear.
Weaknesses: font of class presentations is too small, being in class does not feel useful, random quizzes with no sickness excuses are really tough on students grades
This is a great course
Interesting topic but lectures were pretty dry and it wasnt clear what was important.
Very interesting lectures and assignments

strengths: good overview of the topic, covered many bases
weaknesses: the transition from one unit to the next was a bit disjointed, it could flow better
Horrible lectures, not compatible for learning.
great prof
The group assignments were difficult to write and it was hard to know where you stood in the class

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student who needed an ECON credit like I did, but it was not particularly engaging or rewarding, so would not recommend it if not for an easy class and an ECON credit.
No, I wouldn't.
No, the organization of this class especially the group aspect of it is very unfair and unorganized.
Not really, the assignments aren't hard, but you have to go to class and it isn't interesting. The grading is pretty tough too
Yes, it's a good course to learn about urban inequalities for people who are not that involved in the humanities area.
Yes my favorite econ elective
I'm not sure if I would recommend this, because the content is really interesting, but the group projects were rough.
It is an easy econ elective but can be frustrating in some moments.
Yes, take it for Professor Jaynes

Absolutely not. Not worth the low workload. Terrible terrible class. Most of the assignments are group assignments and I was forced to do the assignments for my team and the professor didnt care. Didnt learn a single thing in this class.
If they can better organize and structure it then yes
Yes if you are looking for low engagement course

If you're someone interested in the intersection of education and economics, go ahead. But warning that a few of the assignments are team based (randomly assigned) and can be very stressful if your team is less proactive.
No, fake gut. Class was boring and group projects with random people made it stressful and unfun
No
Yes
Yes
Gut !!!
nope, DO NOT take this class. it's the worst
if you like group projects then yes
Honestly, not really
Yes, if they are into economics and have interest in the public education system, then this is a course I would recommend to them.
No, unless you wanna credit d it. It's a good class to take cdf.
No. I thought this course would be engaging but sometimes lectures were boring and we never got to the lab component in new haven schools which was disappointing.

I would not recommend this class. The TFs graded some assignments in an unfair way where they expected us to know far more than what was taught to us. There was also never one TF assigned to us so I was unsure who I should have reached out about class concerns.
Yes it is a great Econ elective
Yea if you are looking for an easy credit. The workload is virtually zero. But be aware that there is very little transparency in how things are graded.
Yes very important topic and interesting course
Yes, it gives you a good understanding of the topic at hand
No
yes great learning experience
